Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the father needs to respond
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I stood in the school hallway, my phone buzzing in my pocket. The principal’s words echoed in my mind: “Your son was involved in a bullying incident. We need you to come in and discuss this.” As a father, I felt a heavy responsibility to show up, to guide my child through this mistake, to be present and supportive. But today was also Election Day, and I had just arrived at the polling station. The poll worker handed back my ballot envelope, pointing out the smudged signature. “Please re-sign here, sir, so your vote counts,” she said, her tone polite but firm. I glanced at the clock, knowing the school expected me soon. My heart pounded with the weight of both roles—my son needed me, but so did my civic duty. I could feel the pressure mounting, torn between the expectations of being a good father and a responsible voter, each demanding my immediate attention.
